During the synchronized swimming performances at the 1988 Summer Olympics, music played an instrumental role in setting the tone for the routines. The music used featured a wide variety of genres ranging from classical to pop music. 

The United States team, which won gold in both the duet and team events, used music by American composer George Gershwin for their routines. The music included excerpts from Gershwins’ "Rhapsody in Blue," “Porgy and Bess,” and “An American in Paris.” The Canadian team, which also won gold medals in both categories, used music from Beethoven, Sibelius, and Rachmaninoff for their routines.

Other teams also featured a mix of classical and contemporary music, including Spanish team's performance to Carmen Suite and Russian team's medley of Beatles tunes among other songs.

The inclusion of music in synchronized swimming performances added a new level of creativity and complexity to the sport, allowing athletes to elevate their routines into artistic and technical masterpieces. Since then, musical accompaniment has become a standard feature of synchronized swimming events, with teams carefully selecting music that complements their routine's theme and mood.
